Description: Cypriot terracotta figure of robed man. Torso only, Chest-to-knee fragment of terracotta, with right arm across chest; garment. Flat ‘Asiatic’, or ‘Assyrian’ man. Pressed into one-piece mould. Robe is scalloped, with fringe painted red. Pale buff Cypriot fabric with common black and white inclusions between <0.5mm and (rarely) 4mm across.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ17
Curator's comments: Similar figure as BM 1911,0710.101 and 102, though here only the torso remains. See BM/Big 50126-50127 (BM 1911,0710.101-102) and BM1949,0808.2-3 from Naukratis. ‘from a 26th Dynasty context’ along with BM 1911,0710.92-106 and BM1949,0808.2-3 (Bailey 2008, 186). Such ‘Asiatic’ looking male figurines date to between the mid 7th to late 6th centuries BC, with very close parallels from Cyprus, probably from Arsos workshops (Karageorghis 1995, 19-21, Type I(ii)38. pl. 9.3). Karageorghis argues the ‘Assyrian’ look may coincide with Assyrian domination of Cyprus during the seventh century BC (1995, 21). See AES BM/Big 50129, 50127, 50128, 50130 (AES 1911,0710.102, 1911,0710.103, 1911,0710.105) also from Naukratis. Karageorghis, V. 1995. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. IV. The Cypro-Archaic Period small male figurines. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.034) (Phase 1)
